checkpoint-1.caption: Students can access information, regardless of their sensory abilities.

table.task: Add alternative text to images with content or function, charts, and tables.
Use actual text instead of pictures of text (e.g., memes).
Include written text versions of audio clips.
Add text captions to videos that match what's being said.
Add audio descriptions for important visual elements in videos that aren't mentioned in the dialogue.
Use Word's built-in tools for headings, tables, columns, and lists.
Never rely only on color, shape, or position on a page to explain something.
Use high contrast font colors that stand out from their background colors.
Use simple, readable fonts (like Arial or Calibri) and adequate font size.
Use Word's equation editor instead of images for mathematical formulas.

checkpoint-2.caption: Students can easily navigate and use the document regardless of how they interact with computers.

table.task: Ensure all interactive elements can be accessed with the keyboard alone.
Avoid flashing content that could trigger seizures.
Create a table of contents for longer documents so students can quickly find what they need.
Add bookmarks to key sections of longer documents so students can jump directly to important information.
Use clear link text so students where the link goes the first time the see or hear it.
Ensure students can pause, stop, or adjust the volume of time-based media.

checkpoint-3.caption: Students can easily understand how to use a document, and understand its information.

table.task: Set the document language so screen readers will use the correct pronounciation.
Use consistent layout and formatting so students can maintain their focus on learning.
Use age-appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Define acronyms and abbreviations the first time they appear.
Include relevant visuals alongside complex text to support comprehension.

checkpoint-4.caption: Students can access the document using different technologies and tools that help them learn.

table.task: Run the Accessibility Checker tool to find and fix problems.
Add document properties like title, author, and tags so documents are easier to find and identify.
Consider providing the document in multiple formats (e.g., HTML, PDF).
When saving as PDF, make sure accessibility features carry over.
